greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Positive integers k such that 10*k+6 is equal to the product of two integers ending with 6 (A324297).
comment: All the terms of this sequence are odd.
Why? If an integer 10*k+6 = (10*a+6) * (10*b+6), then k = 10*a*b + 6*(a+b) + 3, so k is odd. - _Bernard Schott_, May 13 2019
link: Stefano Spezia, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: 145 is a term because 26*56 = 1456 = 145*10 + 6. - _Bernard Schott_, May 13 2019
program: isok(k) = {my(n=10*k+6, d=divisors(n)); fordiv(n, d, if (isok6(d) && isok6(n/d), return(1))); return (0);} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Apr 14 2019
results.author: _Stefano Spezia_, Mar 16 2019
